narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-10, if you wish
comments: I audited this course, and so cannot answer most of the questions. The material presented in class was clear.
The knowledge from this kind of course is invaluable for an architect interested in urban planning.

This course is VERY time intensive, but consistently so. Professor Tomlin was not clear at the beginning of the course that he wanted the assignments to explain your reasoning and procedure, so without this explanation many students were left with the understanding that he just wanted nice-looking maps. This is not the case, so in case he is not clear in the beginning of the class know that students should be very explicit in describing the process to get to the final answer.

q.7: The Professor and TA were incredibly helpful. The Professor was always promptly responsive to questions. The Professor and the TA practically guided me through the entire course every step of the way.Q.10: This is a great course and increasingly an indispensable skill to possess!
A course load is a little too much. I wish I could have spent less time on the assignments.

Dana is an absolute champ. The weekly assignments can eat up an incredible amout of time if you let them, but there is always an opportunity to be more efficent. Dana is incredibly generous with his time and absolutely dilligent about answering emailed questions at all hours.A great introductory GIS course.thank you!
The class is very relevant but the work load is very heavy, can be very frustrating without a helpful and very skilled TA - we lucky to have one who has all the qualities.

Qu 4: The assignments were very time consuming relative to other courses.Qu 7b: The TA was overextended, I'm sure. He was very helpful, but there were too many of us competing for his time/having issues with the assignments in the computer lab. There could be 2 TAs for this course.
Our TA was extremely helpful and dedicated so much time to this course; he definitely needs to be commended for his availability and commitment.

I was very happy with the course. The instructor was excellent while the TA was very helpful. One problem i faced was that since the course was more technical, it would have been helpful it we had at least an hour's work in the lab during the class session rather than us arranging a separate session with the TA to workout the tutorials. Besides, since my class clashed with the TA session, so i often found myself working on the assignments on my own. So it would be advisable to have at least some lab work during class session.
The homework assignments. Application really helped me understand the curriculum.
Dana's handouts and tutorials were amazing / very helpful.
Discussions of the practical applications of the tool. Easy to see where these skills will be put to use, professionally and academically.
Gaining a basic understanding of how GIS works.
GIS is a useful tool and Professor Tomlin has created a number of references that will be useful for anyone looking to use this software again in the future.
Instructor's handouts; engaging assignments (bearing in mind that you really do have to dedicate quite a bit of time to them, and most of them are open-ended)
The assignments really forced me to delve deeply into the material and learn the basics of ArcMap.
The way it was taught: interactive, with a lots of follow up sessions with the TA.
Getting practical skills in GIS.
Explanations extreemly clear.Patient instructor.Wonderful hand out materials.Straight foward and transparent grading system.
The information, the handouts, the tutorials - without which life would have been unbearable.
the instructor, his reading materials, and the assignments. the TA was fantastic too.

The broad amount of material it covered, and the handouts, though I feel like there could have been more of them (later in the course, the handouts were used less but I still think they would have been useful if they existed for those later topics).
The detailed handouts. Great reference material.
The lectures rarely took up 3 hours.
The best thing was understanding GIS and its wide application in terms resource planning and resource management. More so the techniques and tools were very engaging.

narratives.question_text: The things about this course most in need of improvement are:
comments: Possible mandatory lab section at least for the preliminary labs
Maybe it could be a little faster paced in the beginning?
I wish the course met in a computer lab...
Connections between early and later material in the course. Feel much was touched upon but never re-addressed.
It is a little bit odd that the class does not take place in a computer lab - only a problem if you don't have a laptop with you, naturally.
Professor Tomlin needs to be more explicit about what he expects in the assignments. He is very vague most of the time.
Duration (really tough to stay tuned for a three-hour fully-lecture class). Would suggest longer breaks in the middle, or make classes twice a week for 1.5 hours.
It's hard to say what should be improved--the goal, I think, is to provide a basic instruction in vector-based mapping, and the course succeeds.
A need to have all students seat at computer stations during the delivering of lectures. By computer stations i mean, students following up step by step on ArcGIS as the lectures are going on.

The professor made a big deal of saying we shouldn't spend excessive time on the homework, but unless a student had worked with GIS before, it was necessary to spend upwards of six or seven hours/week on each assignment to get even an average grade. The professor clearly knows this, because he has taught the class for many years. So, his constant "plea" to not spend too much time on the work started to get patronizing and made those of us who weren't GIS geniuses feel a little dense.
Work load
For the longer home works to go longer before they can be handed in
can't think of a thing

Grading system: much too difficult. It did succeed in making students put in extra effort, but I found that I was doing it at the expense of my other classes, and at times out of exasperation at being "under" or "at" average despite all my hard work.
The pacing of the course was a little slow for me.
My only suggestions is the need to insert at an hour lab work during the class session would help students understand the concepts much better.

narratives.question_text: What was the availability and quality of help you received of the instructor and TA?
comments: Both were at hand for questions, Eric spent a lot of time helping many people in his office hours which were in the computer lab
Quantity and quality of help from both instructor and the TA were outstanding. I frequently consulted with Eric, and he always found time, even outside of his office hours, to help me.
Both the instructor and the TA made themselves more than available to answer questions. The quality of their help was excellent.
Both instructor and TA were extremely responsive. Eric has to be the hardest worked TA I have ever encountered here. Long help session hours with a wide range of student experience and ability.
I got the help I needed
TA was great, but offered a lot more information than necessary, which confused many of the students.
Eric was very helpful, held regular office hours and also responeded to email promptly.
Instructor very responsive through email.TA very helpful in office hours.
The professor is extremely responsive. I did not ask for help from the TA, so I can't comment on his abilities.
They were both readily available and very supportive.

The professor was responsive for help, but condescending. Twice he told me that my question would be used in future classes as dumb questions. The TA was very helpful, though, and I went to him during lab hours and sometimes when I was working on GIS and he was around in Kroon, etc. He was a great TA and balanced out the prof, at least.
They are quite available for questions.
excellent.there is more help available than anyone can make use of.
The TA tried as much as he could to find extra/spare time for me given the time allocated just did not fit with my schedule. That must have cut his reading time short.
excellent, very available

Eric was very helpful and knew his material well. Once I started going to TA sessions, I found that I needed to keep going, because if I tried an assignment on my own, there was likely to be some aspect that I would miss (because assignments were very vague) unless I talked to Eric, who could nudge me in the right direction and remind me of things I was forgetting. I don't think this is quite fair, however--students should be able to complete the assignments to "above average" standard without the assistance of a TA. Also, Eric's hours were a little strange--I think some the day before the hw due date would have been useful.Dana was also helpful over email and willing to assist us anytime, any day.
TA very good. Instructor helpful.
The instructor and TA were extremely helpful.
Both the instructor and TA were always available. The instructor was always available via email while i could always time with the TA for lab work.

narratives.question_text: Discuss if you wish how this course fits into your overall program.
comments: It is a very good tool course and for those interested in garnering tools in graduate school I recommend taking it early in the program so that it can be applied to other learning

I am actually a joint law student, so GIS isn't a traditional course for someone like me to take. But, I studied wildlife and fisheries sciences before I entered law school and FES, and after I completed that program, EVERYONE wanted to know if I was familiar with GIS. The fact that I never took a GIS course in my wildlife program made me feel that it was a gaping hole in my education. I decided to go ahead and take this course to remedy that. Also, I want to practice land use law and will have future clients who use GIS on a regular basis. I think a working familiarity with the software will be invaluable in my future practice.
Great fit. One of the few practical skills classes I have enjoyed.
A good compliment to the other GIS class.
To be an environmental scientist GIS is an essential component of that.
Although I probably won't go on to practice GIS, I know have a much better understanding of it's capabilities and value, something that benefits my area of study.

ArcGIS is very important to my work as a conservationist. Increasingly, there is need to detail characteristics of different land-use patterns; habitat types et cetera on an ecosystem scale. ArcGIS has been shown to be very useful in supporting such processes and invariably sounder management decisions

I feel like I needed this class for future work in land management. I wish we had had an end-of-semester project, rather than just another homework assignment, where we get to apply what we learned to a problem of our own choosing. That would have been helpful.
GIS will definitely be a tool that I use in future FES classes and in my professional career.
This course provides practical technical skills for fieldwork.

GIS has wide application; the visual representation techniques can be used for both planning and impact assessment which is essential for natural resource management and planning. Hence, considering my interest in natural resource management, learning GIS has enabled me to understand the basics of GIS as well as data interpretation techniques.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: Because I want to look at spatial relationships
see answer to question 15
BIN 7 / interest
GIS is a necessary tool in the world of conservation.
To be able to better understand abilities of GIS - and to some degree to be able to use the tools my self.
It seemed to be related to my career goals.
I am interested in learning GIS as a tool that can be useful for spatial understanding of social and ecological issues.
To learn about GIS
To learn about basic GIS capabilities and how to use ArcMap.
Before Yale, i always had to consult with a "specialist" in ArcGIS for even some very basic information. I wanted to geta Formal orientation into the skill set
see above
GIS is somewhat necessary skills in environmental science.
So I can understand basic mapping tools as they are relevant for conservation work
I wanted to improve my GIS skills because I am largely self-taught and knew there was much left to learn.
GIS is widely applicable and good to know.
I wanted to learn GIS so I could apply for a wider range of jobs.

The reason i took GIS is because of its wide application in terms of data analysis and planning. I believe GIS gives me the an extra dimension on data analysis technique and the ability to visually represent data for easier interpretation of data which would be invaluable in terms of natural resource management and planning.

narratives.question_text: Did it live up to your expectations?
comments: This course is more of an introduction into what GIS can be used for generally, but I think it was very important for me to start with a firm understanding of what the program can do even if it wasn't specific to what I will use it for in the future
Yes
Yes
Sure did. Workload lighter than expected.
The course was moving along slow but the information was handed in a very clear format.
Yes and no.
yes, definitely.
Yes
Yes. Although the work was often painful I can truly say that I now have a basic understanding of and facility with ArcMap.
Yes

see above; I thought we would get to do a project, but apparently not. The fact that everything was so abstract/homework assignments were random problems makes me worried I won't actually use this stuff much in the future. I'm less confident with the software than I thought I would be coming out of the class.
Yes, it did.
yes.
Yes
yes

Somewhat--at the beginning of the class, Dana stated that we would learn everything about vector in this class. But there are still processes and tools we did not discuss (I wish we had spent more time on editing/modifying polygons because that menu and tool use is very confusing) and I don't think the handouts covered everything, either.
The class was a little slow for me, but I am comfortable with what I have learned from it.

Yes the course did meet my expectation but it was sometimes very time consuming. However, i enjoyed the class and with the guidance of excellent instructor and TA, learning GIS was fun and enjoyed each class session.

narratives.question_text: Did you get out of it what you expected?
comments: yes
Yes
Yes
Yes.
Because I was an auditor, I did not get as much out of this class as I could have. This was not a fault in the course structure or instructor.
Yes.
yes.
Yes
Yes, absolutely.
Yes i did
see above
Yes, I learned more than I expected.
yes.
Yes
yes

I did learn a ton about GIS capabilities that I did not know existed. I was hoping to feel more proficient with them, but if I had taken the time to really learn them all, I wouldn't have been able to pass any of my other classes.
It's hard to say, since there's a whole other semester on raster GIS. I think after taking both I may be able to say better if I'm competent at GIS.
The class is fun but can be very time consuming. The instructor is excellent and can be reached via email anytime. So, if you can manage time, it is a class you shouldn't miss.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: I responded to a few problem sets via "group work". It helped me to better unravel the problem even as all members of the group contributed some insights into the "how" of the problem set.
Groups not necessary and in fact detrimental to getting the work done

narratives.question_text: For students taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Take advantage of the extra help the professor and TA are willing to give you.
Start the assignments ahead of time, follow along in class

Make sure you do the tutorials before trying to complete the assignments. I liked completing the assignments, or at least starting them in the lab so that I could collaborate with other students and the TA.
Have no fear. I was told to expect a larger time commitment than was actually warranted.
If you audit, make a commitment to stay on top of the material or you will fall behind.

Make sure you start early! Assignments take a very long time. This course is VERY time intensive, but consistently so. Professor Tomlin was not clear at the beginning of the course that he wanted the assignments to explain your reasoning and procedure, so without this explanation many students were left with the understanding that he just wanted nice-looking maps. This is not the case, so in case he is not clear in the beginning of the class know that students should be very explicit in describing the process to get to the final answer.

be prepared to spend quite a lot of time on assignments if you have little or no experience with similar tools.Definitely a course worth taking if you're interested in learning GIS, but not if you're just doing it for the grade.
Start assignments a few days before they are due.

Unless you have prior GIS experience, be prepared for a tremendous workload. If you do the work you will learn a great deal about GIS and ArcMap, but don't expect to be rewarded simply for effort. This can be a difficult course, even for high achievers.

They should do their best to hand in their home work on time. Otherwise, once the home works accumulate, they will be dealing with a fifth course (for those doing four courses) or a sixth course (for those doing five courses). That will require a great deal of time to complete. So, do the best you could to keep abreast with the class.
Manage your time on assignments, otherwise you'll end up spending 15-20 hours doing them.
Don't fall behind on course work and do the extra credit. If you want to play with GIS, take the course, there is plenty of room for experimentation if you are moving more quickly than the class.
Take at least two heavy classes and two lighter classes. Taking this class with 3 others that have similar weight will make you go nuts.
start the assignments early

We were told at the beginning that we would do fine if we spent 6 hrs/week on hw assignments. That's absolutely not true. I probably spent 15-20 hours on many or most of the assignments, aiming for "average" or "above average." I've been told by previous students that the difference between the amount of work you have to put in for an H or HP+ as opposed to an HP is just not worth the effort. I don't know yet how well my effort will pay off, but I don't necessarily think I learned more by stressing out about all the little tricks I could add into my hw assignments. I think a better mastery of the basics should be a stronger focus of the assignments and the grading.
Plan to start your assignments soon after class so that you have plenty of time to ask your questions/get responses and manage your time to complete them.

Don't wait until the last day to do the homework. Spend 3 hours on it over the weekend and then another three hours finishing up during the week. Then it's less stressful, and you have plenty of time to request help from the TA or instructor if there's anything you don't understand.

The course is very time consuming but fun and challenging. However, the course instructor is accessible all the time via email to answer any queries. So, if you can manage time and schedule, its one of the best classes to take.
